# Symmetry

## The Key Insight

Instead of drawing a symmetric pattern...

**Fold the domain** so every point maps to a fundamental region.

Then draw anything—it automatically becomes symmetric.

## Basic Folding

```glsl
// Fold across vertical line at x = 0
if (p.x < 0.0) p.x = -p.x;

// Fold across horizontal line at y = 0
if (p.y < 0.0) p.y = -p.y;
```

Now every point in the plane maps to the first quadrant.

# Reflection Groups

## Half-Space Reflections

A half-space is defined by a line. We reflect points to one side:

```glsl
float halfspace(vec2 p, vec2 normal, float offset) {
    return dot(p, normal) - offset;
}

vec2 reflect_halfspace(vec2 p, vec2 normal, float offset) {
    float d = halfspace(p, normal, offset);
    if (d < 0.0) p -= 2.0 * d * normal;
    return p;
}
```

## Triangle Groups

Three mirrors form a triangle. Repeated reflection creates a tiling.

::: {.callout-note}
The angles must be $\pi/p$, $\pi/q$, $\pi/r$ where $p, q, r$ are integers.

Constraint: $\frac{1}{p} + \frac{1}{q} + \frac{1}{r} = 1$ for Euclidean tilings.
:::

# Hyperbolic Geometry

## The Poincaré Disk

The entire hyperbolic plane fits inside a circle.

{{< shader-demo day3/poincare-disk height="500px" >}}

## Hyperbolic Distance

In the Poincaré disk, distance grows as you approach the boundary.

The boundary circle represents "infinity"—you can never reach it.

## Why Hyperbolic?

::: {.callout-tip}
In hyperbolic geometry: $\frac{1}{p} + \frac{1}{q} + \frac{1}{r} < 1$

This gives infinitely many possible tilings!
:::

## The Folding Algorithm

Same idea as Euclidean, but:

1. Reflect through hyperbolic lines (circular arcs)
2. Use hyperbolic distance for the SDF
3. Count reflections for coloring
